awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Integrating Computation and Experiment to Create Revolutionary Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:   This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site is focused on training the next generation of scientists and engineers with expertise at the intersection of materials science and data analytics. With the goal of providing cutting-edge research to students with limited research opportunities at their home institutions, students are actively recruited from community colleges and primarily undergraduate institutions. Training is occurring through formal instruction, hands-on research, site visits to data-intensive local laboratories and businesses, and preparing and delivering public presentations of research results. The research projects focus on developing transformative structural and electronic materials that enable new technologies and applications. 
 
TECHNICAL DETAILS:  The REU site addresses the NSF Big Idea concerning “Harnessing the Data Revolution” within the context of structural and electronic materials. Students are gaining experience in the generation, curation, and analysis of very large materials science data-sets. Across the structural and electronic materials space research projects are quite diverse, ranging from weldability of high entropy alloys to data-driven additive manufacturing to piezoelectric and thermoelectric material discovery. The research projects are inherently interdisciplinary, involving pairs of faculty members from different departments and their affiliated graduate students. Many of these projects involve strong collaborations with national laboratory and associated user facilities or industry partners. Beyond technical skills development, significant effort is devoted to enhancing students’ professional skills and self-identity as a scientist. Together, these training objectives culminate in the final week with preparing a poster and associated presentation for a national conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Integrating Computation and Experiment to Create Revolutionary Materials (ICECRM) REU program at the Colorado School of Mines ran from 2020 to 2023, focusing on the development of new materials through the integration of computational simulations and experimental research. This program was designed to address the growing challenges and opportunities presented by the vast amounts of data generated in materials science. Over four summers, the program engaged a total of 41 undergraduates (30 students directly funded by the NSF REU award), many from community colleges or primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs).  Continuous evaluation led to ongoing improvements in the program's structure and execution. 

Research:  Participants were involved in challenging materials projects that ranged from modeling gas absorption in metal-organic frameworks to developing new materials for thermoelectric and battery applications. The research was conducted across various departments, including chemical engineering, physics, metallurgy, chemistry, and mechanical engineering, fostering a highly interdisciplinary environment. Most of the research projects involved applications of inorganic materials, often in the energy or semiconductor materials space.  Further, many of the projects involved generating and analyzing substantial datasets, a critical skill set for modern materials science. The NSF Institute for Data-Driven Dynamical Design (ID4), which spans 11 universities, provided some REU students with an opportunity to interact with collaborators across these institutions.  

Technical skills developed by the students varied widely. For example, “Computationally Classifying Coiled-Coil Sequences” introduced students to computationally modeling biomaterials and developing machine-learning based methods to classify their structure.  On the other hand, “High entropy thermoelectric chalcogenides” introduced students to experimentally navigating high-dimensional composition spaces. Students in this project learned about synthesis and structural characterization in quintary alloys.  To date, 4 research papers were published with student co-authors, 9 students were involved in presentations at conferences, and one student received an NSF GRFP Honorable Mention based on their summer project.  

Recruitment: Students from community colleges were actively recruited through both information sessions and collaboration with the Colorado/Wyoming Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (COWYAMP).  In total, community college students represented 22% of the participants, and an additional 27% of students came from primarily undergraduate institutions. Overall, 76% of students were from underrepresented groups in STEM. 

Pandemic: The 2020 summer was entirely remote and the 2021 summer was a mixture of remote and in-person students due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In these years, students’ projects were typically computational in nature - for example, two students studied low dimensional materials using ab initio calculations.  These years were challenging due to the limited coding experience and the Zoom-based mentorship.  The transition to a fully in-person cohort in 2022 was advantageous for student learning, cohort development, and building identity as a scientist.  

Professional development: Throughout their involvement, students received extensive professional development training, focusing particularly on research proposal writing to enhance their understanding of the research context, motivation, and future trajectories.  Students were trained in being effective reviewers of each other’s writing and subsequently engaged in significant peer review of proposal drafts.  Ethical training was also a crucial component of their education, ensuring they understood the broader implications of their research activities.

Long term effect: The majority of students who have participated in this REU are still participating in research six months and one year after completion of the REU, according to follow-up surveys from all years and student LinkedIn profiles. As an example, of the 13 students from the 2022 cohort, three of them are currently in PhD programs (two of these students are enrolled at CSM), four them are completing MS degrees this year, and all 6 of the remaining students, all of whom are still completing their undergraduate degrees, participated in at least one additional research experience. Therefore students who participate in the ICECRM REU are likely to pursue additional research experiences and a career in STEM.
